newsitem.title: ALBANIA: Albanian rebels in Sarande reject amnesty offer.
newsitem.headline: Albanian rebels in Sarande reject amnesty offer.

text.p: Albanian rebels holding this southern port town on Friday rejected a government offer of amnesty if they surrendered their weapons.
Fuat Karali, a former police officer and now a member of the town's rebel council, said the rebels would hold Sarande until President Sali Berisha resigned and general elections were held.
"We're not giving up our weapons until Berisha resigns. Down with the dictatorship," Fuat Karali told a cheering mass rally in the main square.
Berisha, facing a popular uprising in Albania's south, set a 48-hour period from Friday when the rebels could surrender their arms in return for amnesty.
But there appeared to be no takers in Sarande, where defence barricades were being strengthened and hundreds of rebels were organising the town to withstand a long siege.
Karali, speaking on behalf of the new rebel council, ordered parents to confiscate weapons from children 18 or under because of accidents in recent days.

Anti-government riots swept Sarande last weekend and weapons were looted from state armouries. Thousands of locals, including pre-teenage children, have wandered through Sarande firing a variety of weapons.
Albania has been rocked by anti-government protests and riots since January when five get-rich-quick pyramid investment schemes failed, wiping out the savings of thousands of families.
Rebels have seized towns in the relatively prosperous southern region of Europe's poorest state, including Vlore, Tepelene and Sarande.
Captured army tanks guard the eastern entrance to Sarande and heavily-armed rebels have dug in with anti-aircraft guns. Rebel guards have been posted at government buildings and the hospital.
Residents said petrol was running low and hospital director Petraq Kaci said he needed plasma and a portable x-ray machine to help locate bullets in the wounded.
Rebels clashed with regular army troops about 20 kms (12 miles) east of Sarande on Wednesday. Four rebels and at least two soldiers were wounded.
The hospital was also treating two suspected secret police agents who had been savagely beaten by a crowd.
